gurmukhi: QrkMq huqo iek ic`q nBM ] Aiq au`jl AMg surMg suBM ] nhI Awn iblokq Awp idgM ] idh BwNiq rhXo gf m`C mnM ]367]
transliteration: Tharakant Houto Ik Chitt Nabhan|| At(i) Ujjal An Suran Soubhan|| Nahiaan Bilokat Aap Digadg|| Eh Bhaant(i) Rahyo Gad Machchh Manan||367||
translation: With concentrated mind, he was stable at one place in the sky and his limbs were extremely white and pretty; his mind was absorbed in the fish and he was not seeing anyone else.367.

gurmukhi: qhwN jwie mhwN mun m`jn kY ] auiT kY hir iDAwn lgw suc kY ] n tro qb lO vh m`C ArI ] rQ sUr AiQE nh fIT trI ]368]
transliteration: Tahaan Jaae Mahaan Mounndmajjan Kai|| Outh(i) Kai Har(i) Dhiaan Lagad Souch Kai|| Na Daro Tab Lau Bah Machchhdaree|| Rath Soor Athio Nah Dith Daree||368||
translation: These the Guru went and took bath and getting up mediated on the Lord, but that enemy of the fish, concentrated his attention on the fish even till sunset.368.

gurmukhi: QrkMq rhw nB m`C ktM ] rQ Bwn hitE nhI DXwn CutM ] Aivlok mhwN mun moih rihE ] gur sqRsvoN kr qws kihE ]369]
transliteration: Tharkant Rahaa Nabh Machchh Katan|| Rath Bhaan Hatio Nahidhyaan Chhoutan|| Avilok Mahaa Mounndmoh(i) Rahio|| Gur Satrasavon Kar Taas Kahio||369||
translation: He remained unwavered in the sky and did not even think of the sunset; seeing him, the great sage observed silence and accepted him as the Seventeenth Guru.369.
End of the description of the adoption of the Fishing Bird as the Seventeenth Guru.
Now begins the description of the adoption of a Hunter as the Eighteenth Guru

gurmukhi: kir m`jn goibMd gwie gunM ] auiT jwiq Bey bn m`iD munM ] jh swl qmwlm Fwl lsY ] rQ sUrj ky pg bwj PsY ]370]
transliteration: Kar(i) Majjan Gobind Gade Gounan|| Outh(i) Jaat(i) Bhae Ban Maddh(i) Mounndng|| Jah Saal Tamaalam Dhaal Lasai|| Rath Sooraj Ke Pag Baaj Phasai||370||
translation: After taking bath and singing the praises of the Lord, the sage went into the forest, where there were the trees of saal and tamaal and in the dense shade of those trees, the light of the sun could not reach.370.

gurmukhi: Aivlok qhwN iek qwl mhwN ] irK jwq Bey iqh jog jhwN ] qh p`qx m`D lhXo miRghw ] iqn soBq kMcn su`D pRBw ]371]
transliteration: Avilok Tahaan Ik Taal Mahaan|| Rikh Jaat Bhae Tih Jog Jahaan|| Tah Pattan Maddh Lahyo Mrigadaa|| Tin Sobhat Kanchanndsuddh Prabhaa||371||
translation: There the sage a tank and also within the foliage he saw a hunter looking splendid like gold.371.

gurmukhi: kir sMiDq bwx kmwx isqM ] miRg mwrq kot kror ikqM ] sB sYn munISr sMig ley ] jh kwnn Qo qh jwq Bey ]372]
transliteration: Kar(i) Sandhit Baan Kamaan Sitan|| Mrig Maarat Kot Daror Kitan|| Sabh Sain Mounndeshar San(i) Lae|| Jah Kaanan Tho Tah Jaat Bhae||372||
translation: He had in his hand a bow and arrows of white colour, with which he had killed many deer; the sage came out from that side of the forest alongwith his people.372.

gurmukhi: knkM duiq aujl AMg sny ] muinrwj mnM irq rwj bny ] irK sMg sKw ins bhuq ley ] iqh bwrD dUj ibloik gey ]373]
transliteration: Kankan Dout(i) Ujal Ag Sane|| Mounndraaj Manan Rit Raaj Bane|| Rikh San Sakhaa Nis Bagout Lae|| Tih Baaradh Dooj Bilok(i) Gad||373||
translation: Many persons of the magnificence of gold, accompanied the sage Dutt and they all saw that hunter.373.

gurmukhi: irK bolq Gorq nwd nvM ] iqh Taur kulwhl auc huAM ] jl pIvq Taur hI Taur munI ] bn m`iD mno irK mwl bnI ]374]
transliteration: Rikh Dolat Ghorat Naad Navan|| Tih Thaur Kulaahal Ouch Huan|| Jal Peevat Thaur Mounnde|| Ban Maddh(i) Mano Rich Maal Banee||374||
translation: Those sages raised thunderous sound an dreadful tumult at that place and scattering at various places they began to have their food and drink.374.

gurmukhi: Aiq au`jl AMg ibBUq Dry ] bhu BwNiq inXws Anws kry ] invlXwidk srbM krm kIey ] irK srb chUM ck dws QIey ]375]
transliteration: At(i) Ujjal An Bibhoot Ddare|| Bahu Bhaant(i) Niyaas Anaas Dare|| Nivalyaadik Sarban Karam Keee|| Rikh Sarab Chahoon Chak Daas Theee||375||
translation: Those sages smeared their white bodies with ashes, practiced various postures and performed various Karmas like Neoli (Purging of intestines), while wandering in all the four directions.375.

gurmukhi: AnBMg AKMf AnMg qnM ] bhu swDq nXws sMnXws bnM ] jt sohq jwnuk DUr jtI ] iSv kI jnu jog jtw pRgtI ]376]
transliteration: Anbhan Akhannddanan Tanan|| Bahu Saadhat Nyaas Sannyaas Banan|| Jat Sohat Jaanouk Dhoor Jatee|| Shiv Kijan(u) Jog Jataa Pragadee||376||
translation: They absorbed themselves in various practices completely without the element of lust; their matted locks appeared the manifestation of the matted locks of Shiva.376.
